input:

46:08 Caption: Robert Snodgrass (Hull City) swings in the corner, but fails to find any of his teammates. One of the defenders reacts superbly to get it clear.
47:57 Caption: The referee blows his whistle to end the first half and the players are now heading to their respective dressing rooms.
47:59 Caption: Well, a decent first half here. It's certainly not boring, but not the best match either. The away side is controlling this game. The home players attempt to beat the opposition's defence using mostly counter-attacks. The away team tries to prevail using combination football.

48:59 Caption: What an entertaining encounter between these two teams. Let's hope there will more of the same in their other games. You have to say that the visitors have been the better side. The home team tried to find the weakness in the opposition's defence mostly using rapid counter-attacks, while the away team played possession football.
    

    #######TASK 
    Provide a factually correct and detailed textual description of the game compiled from the information presented above from different sources, in more than 1000 words.
            "Cap:": represents the captions published in the online portal usually within 30 seconds of the event.
            "E:" represents events recorded exactly after the event happened.
    Don't mention sources of information like commentators or captions, write as if you saw them live.
summary:
At the KCOM Stadium, Hull City faced a formidable opponent in Arsenal, and the match was an electrifying affair with the visitors eventually running out 4-1 victors. From the outset, it was clear that Arsenal had come with a game plan to dominate possession and create scoring opportunities. Hull City, however, were not going to roll over easily and had moments of their own to threaten Petr Cech’s goal.

The match kicked off with Hull City taking the initial possession, but almost immediately, the ball went out of play, a harbinger of the intense and tightly contested game that was to follow. Hull's early throw-in and subsequent foul gave Arsenal their first chance of the game. Notably, a beautiful through ball aimed for Adama Diomande by Hull was efficiently intercepted by Petr Cech, showcasing his alertness.

Arsenal, led by their dynamic attacking unit, started exerting pressure. Alexis Sanchez received a perfect pass inside the penalty box only to fire his shot high above the bar. The Gunners were showing their intent, with Ozil and Iwobi dictating the pace in the middle. Despite a couple of wasted opportunities, Arsenal did not relent. Hector Bellerin’s attempt to pierce into the box was neutralized by Hull's defense, characterizing the initial few minutes.

Then, in the 16th minute, the breakthrough came. Alex Iwobi unleashed a shot that deflected off Alexis Sanchez and wrong-footed Hull goalkeeper Eldin Jakupovic to give Arsenal the lead. Hull had the next opportunity via a corner taken by Robert Snodgrass; however, it was poorly executed, nullifying any offensive threat.

The game’s first yellow card appeared when Santi Cazorla was penalized for his foul in the middle of the field. Despite the heated setup, Arsenal continued their assault with more shots on target that Hull’s Jakupovic had to be at his best to save. This initial period showcased an Arsenal side that was in control, where periods of play were punctuated by expert passing and pinpoint attacks.

As the first half headed towards its conclusion, a pivotal moment occurred when Hull's Jake Livermore handled the ball inside his area, awarding Arsenal a penalty and reducing Hull to ten men as Livermore received a red card. Alexis Sanchez stepped up but was denied by a fantastic save from Jakupovic. Although Arsenal missed the immediate opportunity to extend their lead, they maintained the pressure, coming close through a set-piece header from Laurent Koscielny which was again deftly saved.

Hull, despite being a man down, sought to equalize through counters, but Arsenal's defensive line held firm. The first half ended with Arsenal showing dominance but Hull City not entirely ruled out from the contest. 

Resuming the second half, Arsenal wasted no time reaffirming their command. Theo Walcott doubled their lead with a splendid chipped finish after a precise assist from Iwobi. This further compounded Hull's problems, emphasizing Arsenal’s clinical prowess in front of goal.

Hull tried to claw back into the game through substitutions, with Ryan Mason replacing Tom Huddlestone and later bringing on Dieumerci Mbokani for Abel Hernandez. It became a battle to manage sustained pressure from Arsenal’s continued forays towards goal. Despite Hull’s best efforts, an offside call nullified any progress they sought to make from free kicks and set pieces.

Although a remarkable attempt from Alexis Sanchez tested Jakupovic again, Arsenal stayed relentless, moving the ball with dexterous ease. With some intricate build-up play, another substitution added fresh legs to the pitch, Granit Xhaka coming on to maintain midfield stability.

Hull City’s sliver of hope came through a penalty of their own. Robert Snodgrass capitalized on the opportunity, sending Petr Cech in the wrong direction to make it 1-2 and reinvigorating the home supporters’ belief. However, Arsenal’s tactical acumen and depth in squad shone through as they subsequently introduced Mohamed Elneny into the fray, replacing the tireless Iwobi.

A defensive misstep allowed Alexis Sanchez to pounce on a rebound, extending Arsenal's lead once again with a powerfully placed shot into the top right corner. This effectively sealed Hull City's fate as they struggled to regain momentum.

Arsene Wenger’s side continued to showcase their attacking mindset till the final whistle. Granit Xhaka, serving as an exclamation to their performance, struck a thunderous long-range shot to cement Arsenal’s fourth goal, a moment of individual brilliance that highlighted their dominance and creative play.

In the closing stages, despite Hull’s attempts to break forward, it was evident that Arsenal had a firm hold. Lucas Perez replaced Theo Walcott to see out the game and added another layer to their well-strategized side. Hull, with bright moments and individual efforts, found themselves kind of chasing shadows against a team that utilized possession and positional play to full effect.

The referee’s final whistle brought an end to a thrilling encounter. Hull City’s endeavor was overshadowed by Arsenal’s quality and depth across the park. The Gunners’ ability to create and finish opportunities proved too much for a spirited but ultimately outclassed Hull City squad. Overall, the game not only highlighted Arsenal's form but also delivered a comprehensive look into the tactical and player management elements that defined their convincing 4-1 win.
